In 12 out of these 13 cases (12/13 ≈ 0.923), linear interpolation produced imputed positions within 5 meters of actual recorded positions when validated against ground-truth AIS logs, indicating high accuracy under constant-velocity assumptions.  
2. explanation_composer.regulatory_rule_cue:
Traffic Separation Scheme Navigation Protocol (applicable to cargo vessels navigating within designated maritime lanes; spatial anchor: nearby shipping lanes with structured traffic flow)
Operational Protocol Rationale: The selected behavior reflects typical navigation for a cargo vessel operating in a regulated traffic separation scheme, where vessels are expected to maintain steady speed and follow predefined curved routes to ensure safe separation from opposing traffic. The observed stable propulsion, gradual course adjustment, and minimal heading variation align with autopilot-assisted transit along a gently curving channel, which is standard practice in such environments to avoid abrupt maneuvers and maintain predictability. This pattern is consistent with vessels of similar size and draft navigating comparable segments, and it contrasts with behaviors involving frequent course corrections or speed changes, which would suggest maneuvering in congested waters or port approaches—neither of which apply here. Given the absence of hazardous cargo and the vessel’s continued "under way using engine" status, sustained transit along a fixed, curved route remains the most operationally sound interpretation.
